question: What's the matter?
answer: It's Ferris!

question: What's wrong?
answer: What's wrong? For Christ's sake! Look at him!

question: Ferris?
answer: He doesn't have a fever. But he says his stomach hurts and he's seeing spots.

question: What's the matter, Ferris?
answer: Feel his hands. They're cold and clammy.

question: Should you call the doctor?
answer: He doesn't want me to.

question: Food...shelter...no...yes... Hello?
answer: Cameron! What's happening?

question: Very little.
answer: How do you feel?

question: Shredded.
answer: Is your mother in the room?

question: She's not home. Where are you?
answer: Home.

question: Humongous reaches down and grabs a real nitrous oxide valve. He gives it a twist.
answer: He throws himself back against the chair.

question: The force of the rapid acceleration of his vehicle throws Humongous back in his seat.
answer: He bounces himself in the chair to simulate the bumpy high speed ride.

question: The was wagon hurtles down the road.
answer: He rears back in horror.

question: The war wagon is heading for a head-on collision with the tanker truck.
answer: Arms outstretched, head thrown back, braced for collision.

question: I'm really sorry about your brother.
answer: What're you sorry for? I have to live with the trouser snake.

question: No, I mean I heard he's really sick.
answer: Who said he's sick.

question: I don't trust this kid any further than I can throw him!
answer: With your bad knee, you better not throw anybody, Ed.

question: What's so dangerous about a character like Ferris Bueller is that he gives the good kids bad ideas. The last thing I need at this point in my career is fifteen hundred Ferris Bueller disciples running around these halls.
answer: He's very popular, Ed. Sportos, motorheads, geeks, sluts, pinheads, dweebies, wonkers, richies, they all adore him.

question: That's exactly why I have to catch him this time. To show these kids that the example he sets is a first class ticket to nowhere.
answer: Ooo. You sounded like Dirty Harry just now.

question: It's completely cool. He's just checking up on me. Now, listen to me. I'm working on getting some heavy bucks out of him. So, the least you can do is hurry up and get over here. Bye. Sorry, Dad. The moment before you called, I had a chest spasm and I blew lung fluid all over the place. It was making me ill looking at it. But gee, it's sure great of you to call. I'm sure there're alot of fathers who wouldn't take time out from their busy schedules to call a dumb, sick teenager.
answer: Hey, pal, what was I supposed to do?

question: Give yourself some credit, Dad. It was a mammoth gesture. It's like those savings bonds you used to give me every Christmas. It was that kind of concern. You had to work hard for the money to buy those things, right?
answer: Not any harder than anybody else.

question: You work so hard I'll bet you don't even remember where those bonds are, right?
answer: Wrong.

question: Oh, yeah? You're pulling my leg. You're just trying to cheer me up.
answer: Like hell I am. They're in a shoebox in my closet.

question: Was that a class move or what? The guy gave it up faster than a drunk Catholic girl. I hope my kids don't pull this shit on me. Of course, if they didn't, they'd be dumb and abnormal and they'd probably never move out of my house and I'd have to support them until I die. I take it back. Dad? All this talking has made me kind of light-headed. I think I better lie down.
answer: Okay, pal. You take care. I'll call you after lunch.

question: You don't have to, Dad.
answer: I want to. Bye now.

question: She, like the others, watches the nurse curiously.
answer: Sloane Peterson?

question: Sits up in her seat.
answer: She's a picture of compassion and understanding. May I see you outside for a moment? There's been an emergency.

question: A smile curls across her lips. As she gathers her books she looks to the GIRL next to her. Dead grandmother.
answer: Dead grandmother.

question: Dead grandmother?
answer: That's what Mr. Peterson said. I had Florence Sparrow notify Sloane.

question: Who's this girl's going with?
answer: It's so hard to tell. I see her alot with Ferris Bueller.

question: Could you get me Mr. Peterson's daytime number?
answer: Edward Rooney's office. Yes. Can you hold? Thank you. It's Mr. Peterson. Do you still want his number?

question: Ed Rooney. How are you today, sir? I heard. And, gosh, I'm all broken up. Huh? Oh, sure. I'd be happy to release Sloane. You produce a corpse and I'll release Sloane. I want to see this dead grandmother firsthand. It's Ferris Bueller. Nervy litttle punk. I'm gonna set a trap and let his walk right into it! That's right. Cart the stiff in and I'll turn over your daughter. It's school policy. Was this your mother?
answer: Ed Rooney's office. Hold, please.

question: I'll tell you want, you don't like my policies, you can just come on down and smooch by big old ugly ass. You hear me? What!?
answer: Ferris Bueller's on line two.

question: This isn't over yet, buster. You just make sure my daughter's out in front of the school in ten minutes. Do you read me? Call me sir, goddamn it! That's better. I'm scared shitless, Ferris! What is Rooney guesses my voice!
answer: Impossible. You're doing great.

question: I don't have all day to bark at you so I'll make this short and sweet.
answer: Great!

question: I want my daughter out in front of the school in ten minutes. By herself. I don's want anyone around... What'd I do?
answer: Out in front my herself? It's too suspicious! He'll think something's up, moron. Cover it.

question: You do it!
answer: Talk!

question: Why'd you hit me?!
answer: Where's your brain?!

question: Why'd you hit me?!
answer: Where's your brain?!

question: Why'd you hit me?
answer: Where's your brain?

question: I asked you first.
answer: How can we pick up Sloane if Rooney's going to be there with her?!

question: I said for her to be there alone and you freaked!
answer: My, God, you're so stupid! I didn't hit you, I lightly slapped you.

question: You hit me. Look, don't ask me to participate in your crap if you don't like the way I do it! I was home, sick. You get me out of bed, being me over here, make me jeopardize my future, make me do a phoney phone call on a dean of students, a man who could squeeze my nuts into oblivion and then you deliberately hurt my feelings.
answer: I didn't deliberately hurt your feelings.

question: Oh, really?
answer: Yeah, really.

question: Hey, Ferris? Have a nice life.
answer: Cameron?

question: Stick it up your ass, Ferris.
answer: Cameron, I'm sorry. I didn't mean to jam you. It was uncalled for.

question: You're serious?
answer: Dead serious.

question: Thanks.
answer: You did screw up through, right? Not that is was necessarily all you fault. Right?

question: Why?
answer: To fix this situation, I'm going to have to ask you for a small favor.

question: 1958 Ferrari 250 GTS California. Less than a hundred were made. It has a market value of $265,000. My father spent three years restoring it. It is joy, it is his love, it is his passion.
answer: It is his fault he didn't lock the garage.

question: Ferris, my father loves this car more than life itself. We can't take is out.
answer: A man with priorities so far out of whack doesn't deserve such a fine automobile.

question: He never drives it, Ferris. He just rubs it with a diaper.
answer: We can't pick up Sloane in your car, Cameron. Rooney'd never believe Mr. Peterson drives that piece of shit.

question: It's not a piece of shit.
answer: It's a piece of shit. Don't worry about it. I don't even have a piece of shit. I have to envy yours. Look, I'm sorry but there's nothing else we can do.

question: He knows the mileage, Ferris. He has it tatooed on his wrist.
answer: He doesn't trust you?

question: No.
answer: Alright, look, this is real simple. He puts his arm around Cameron. Whatever miles we put on it, we'll take off.

question: How?
answer: We'll drive home backwards.

question: Are you crazy?! Put the top back up!
answer: This is perfect top-down weather.

question: What about Rooney?
answer: Cameron, the more obvious we are, the less likely we are to get caught.

question: That makes no sense whatsoever.
answer: The adult mind is a suspicious machine. Stay down, man.

question: Howcome it's my Dad's car and I'm taking all the risk and I have to ride back here?
answer: I don't have an explanation.

question: If you had access to a car like this would you take it back right away? Would you give up feeling like a ton just to ease your best friend's tension? Either would I.
answer: Ferris Bueller?

question: He's at the window. On either shoulder are Cameron and Sloane. Ferris smiles. Cameron blanches. Hello, Mrs. Froeling. How are you?
answer: She pats the rock-solid mass of blue hair. In doing so she locates a missing ball point pen. She withdraws it from the hair and smiles at it's reappearance. I passed a kidney stone Tuesday, so I'm a little pooped but other than that, I'm as chipper as can be. Say, should you be in school?

question: He lays his savings bonds on the counter. Me? I'm out of school, Mrs. Froeling. In fact. I'm married. This is my wife...Madonna. And this is my brother-in-law, ZZ Top. ZZ, this is Mrs. Froeling.
answer: Is Top a Slavic name?

question: Something's going on, goddamn it.
answer: There's a railroad strike.

question: And I'm going to stop it!
answer: My brother-in-law'll appreciate it.

question: What?
answer: My brother-in-law rides the train to work.

question: It could get stolen, wrecked, scratched, you name it.
answer: I'll give the guy a five to watch it.

question: What guy?
answer: You speak English? Great. I want to you take extra special care of this vehicle, okay? I appreciate it. See what a finski can do to a person's attitude? He's going to treat it like a beautiful woman.

question: This is the world's tallest building. From our vantage point here on the 103 floor, we are provided with a view of four states.
answer: Do you think the car's alright?

question: Illinois, Michigan, Wisconsin and my personal favorite, Indiana.
answer: I don't feel good, Ferris. Are we gonna stay long?

question: Do you love me?
answer: Do you love me?

question: I asked you first.
answer: Yes. You?

question: Yes.
answer: Would I trash a day of education to be with you if I didn't love you?

question: Yes.
answer: Would I risk damaging a deep and wonderfully enriching relationship with my parents if I didn't love you?

question: Yes.
answer: Would I have introduced you as my wife if I didn't love you?

question: Wait a minute. That was a lie.
answer: True. Would you want to get married? I mean if I wasn't an asshole.

question: Sure.
answer: Today? I'm game.

question: No way!
answer: I'll do it, if you will.

question: I'll do it, if you will.
answer: You need a blood test.

question: Huh?
answer: If your blood's not compatible, you could produce a pinhead. The state requires a blood test.

question: So?
answer: So, you can't get married today.

question: Tomorrow?
answer: If you get a blood test today.

question: It makes me puke. Seeing people treat each other like that. It's like the car. He loves the car. He hates his wife.
answer: My parents are divorced. So what? It's not like it doesn't happen ten thousand times a day.

question: Just because it happens doesn't make it right. Are you comfortable with it?
answer: No. It's not something I can get comfortable with. I've tried. Are yours divorced?

question: They may as well be.
answer: Do you think they're staying together because of you? Do they like you?

question: Yeah. Sure.
answer: Consider this...my father canned me and my brother and my Mom for a twenty five year old dipso with fake tits. He dropped us like a rock. Everything was cool at our house. I thought so. We all thought so. Then BLAM! It's over.

question: May I help you?
answer: Yes. I'm Abe Frohman. Party of three for 12:00. Is there a problem?

question: You're Abe Frohman?
answer: I'm Abe Frohman.

question: I'm sorry, son. I'm very busy right now. If you have trouble finding the door...
answer: Are you suggesting that I'm not who I say I am?

question: Not a chance in the world. Ask for Abe Frohman.
answer: I appreciate your understanding.

question: Don't grovel, Charles. Just leave us to our repast and all will be forgotten.
answer: Enjoy your luncheon.

question: Ferris Bueller's days are numbered. I'm gonna bust his buns.
answer: Why? What's the point?

question: Why? Because I'm sick of the little dope. He manipulates my parents, he does whatever he wants, whenever he wants and he never gets nailed. Well, babe, today I'm the hammer.
answer: I think he's cute.

question: Sweetie, it's an established fact that you have no taste. Ferris is not cute. He's not charming. He's not nice. He's not a wonderful person. He's an ignorant mule and the sooner everybody in this school comes to that realization the better off we'll all be. See? My brother strokes you, you sympathize with him, I get pissed off and this is what happens! Let me tell you something. I study hard, I work hard, I'm polite, I'm considerate, I'm friendly and fair to all kinds of people. Except morons. I try to be everything a good, decent person should be and you know what?
answer: Everybody thinks you're an asshole.

question: Excuse me?
answer: I don't think you're an asshole.

question: Who does? Rachel? Rachel's a dirt bag. Who else?
answer: I don't know. Just forget it.

question: Forget that everybody thinks I'm an asshole? Would you like everybody to think you're an asshole?
answer: Not everybody thinks you're an asshole. Mr. Rooney likes you.

question: Oh, hey. That's exciting. A fat fifty year old clod with B.O. likes me. Would everybody be happier if maybe I were to die in a flaming car accident or something?
answer: Maybe if you didn't cat like and asshole...

question: Am I acting like an asshole?
answer: I didn't mean it that way.

question: I this a conspiracy to shit all over me or something? Is my brother behind this? Tell me if he is or I'll sock your tits.
answer: You really do have a problem, Jeanie.

question: Me? I have a problem?
answer: Somebody who threatens to sock people's tits has a problem.

question: Alright. How about if I sock your face?
answer: Take a walk, Jeanie.

question: I knew it was a mistake letting Ferris order for us.
answer: What are you doing?

question: What is this shit?
answer: You got me. I don't speak French. I think it's a land-based beefoid creature. Splendid.

question: Really?
answer: Superb. Good? Yo, Clouseau! I have a growth on my brain that causes memory lapses. Could you tell me what we ordered here? Uh, huh. And what might that be? As in the gland that has important functions in digestion and metabolism?

question: Superb. Good? Yo, Clouseau! I have a growth on my brain that causes memory lapses. Could you tell me what we ordered here? Uh, huh. And what might that be? As in the gland that has important functions in digestion and metabolism?
answer: He continues his questioning.

question: ...That secretes a thick, colorless fluid containing digestive enzymes? The home of the world famous isles of Langerhans?
answer: He pats his mouth with his napkin. He looks to Cameron and Sloane. He raises a finger, holds it a beat and gives a cue. He watches Sloane and Cameron then glances at the waiter.

question: Yeah. Everybody's dead, it's real cold and the skiing's for shit. My step-father's always going off about how when he was young he was committed to all these causes.
answer: He's full of shit. All the old hippies are full of shit.

question: He says I don't care about things like he did.
answer: What's he care about now?

question: Baldness, fatty meats and money.
answer: I rest my case.

question: It's reprehensible to squeal on your own flesh and blood...but it's for his own good. His cavalier attitude will get him into trouble later in life...and it'll continue to piss me off and I'll get so wadded-up that it'll cause cervex cancer and he'll ruin my life. Screw him.
answer: Hello, Jeanie. Who's bothering you now?

question: Is Dean Rooney in?
answer: I'm sorry, he's out. Can I help you?

question: I seriously doubt it. When's he back?
answer: I don't know. He left the grounds on personal business.

question: The blood evacuates his face. He stares at the girl.
answer: She stares at him. She picks up her Coke. She puts the straw to her lips and sucks.

question: He's still staring. He can't think of anything to say.
answer: Holding the straw in the mouth, she draws it out of the cup. She raises it, pointing it directly in Rooney's face.

question: He squints
answer: She blows a strawful of Coke in Rooney's face.

question: I think I broke my thumb.
answer: Can we leave now?

question: You want to leave? We just got here.
answer: You got a call, you broke your thumb, what's left to do? No wonder you're always sick.

question: I love him.
answer: It's hard not to. Stop...water...want...

question: Do you believe in reincarnation?
answer: Huh?

question: Do you believe that you lived before?
answer: Yeah. Sort of.

question: DO you ever wonder what you were?
answer: I don't have to wonder. I know. I was a tractor tire.

question: What were you in a previous life?
answer: I'm not sure but I think I know who Ferris was.

question: Hannibal.
answer: From the A-Team?

question: No. The guy who rode the elephants into Switzerland.
answer: I think if he was anybody, he was Magellan. You know, the guy who went around the world. I could see him ignoring popular belief and taking off on some impossible mission.

question: The future's worse for a boy, isn't it? A girl can always bail out and have a baby and get some guy to support her.
answer: That's a pretty grim thought.

question: True, but it's an option. No options is worse.
answer: I don't know what I'm gonna do.

question: College.
answer: Yeah, but to do what?

question: What are you interested in?
answer: Nothing.

question: Me either.
answer: What do you think Ferris is gonna do?

question: This is Ed Rooney, Ferris. I'd like to have a word with you.
answer: I'm sorry I can't come to the door right now. I'm very ill and I'm afraid that in my weakened condition, I could take a nasty spill down the stairs and subject myself to further school absenses.

question: B.S. Come down here.
answer: You can reach my parents at their places of business. Thank you for stopping by. I appreciate your concern for my well-being. It will be remembered long after this illness has past.

question: I'm not leaving until you come down and talk to me.
answer: Have a nice day.

question: I'm not leaving, Ferris.
answer: Who is it?

question: Don't get smart with me Ferris!
answer: I'm sorry I can't come to the door right now. I'm very ill and I'm afraid that in my weakened condition... You may reach my parents at their places of business. I appreciate your conern for my well-being. It will be remembered long after...

question: She's probably schizophrenic.
answer: Ferris, this is nauseating me. Really. I'm losing respect for you by the bucket.

question: You don't think it's amazing that we got in?
answer: Who wants to get in?

question: Cameron looks like a toddler, for Christ's sake. I'm talking about a major achievement in false identification.
answer: I'm not interested in watching someone jiggle their mammary glands.

question: Point well taken. But consider why she does it. Why she does it and you don't.
answer: I'm not a tramp.

question: So... So, Yuri, how long have you been in America? What's your overall impression? Better than Russia? Clearly you've never been to an American high school.
answer: It's getting late, Ferris. I have to get the car home. I know you don't care, but it means my ass.

question: You think I don't care?
answer: I know you don't care.

question: Howdy!
answer: Who is it?

question: Focus on Flowers. I have a delivery.
answer: I'm sorry but I can't come to the door right now. I'm very ill and I'm afraid...

question: As I heard it from our mailman he was supposedly born with only half a kidney.
answer: Have a nice day.

question: Thank you. I don't know the details. But my boss had to send to Milwaukee to get more orchids. He's very popular. Nobody's home here?
answer: No.

question: You gonna be around for awhile?
answer: I imagine so.

question: You wanna keep an eye on these? It really touches me that so many people are rallying behind this guy. I guess there's hope for the human race afterall. Gotta run.
answer: Oh, Christ...

question: Well, Boyd, how are you bearing up? Did I tell you I have a son your age?
answer: Twice.

question: His name is Ferris. I think you'd like him.
answer: Is he going up in the space shuttle in September?

question: Not that I know of.
answer: I knew he was bullshitting. How do you watch your mouth?

question: Do you know my son?
answer: I don't think it's cute. I think it's fun.

question: We have enough cash left for a quick flight to Peoria and back.
answer: Very funny.

question: Cameron? How many miles did you say this thing had when we left?
answer: One hundred and twenty six and halfway between three and four tenths. Why? How many miles are on it now?

question: Drugs?
answer: No, thank you. I'm straight.

question: I meant, are you here for drugs?
answer: Why are you here?

question: Drugs.
answer: I don't know why I'm here.

question: Then why don't you go home?
answer: Why don't you put your thumb up your butt?

question: You want to talk about your problem?
answer: With you? Are you serious?

question: Yeah, I'm serious.
answer: Blow yourself. You really want to know what's wrong? Alright. If you've got the time, I've got the troubles. In a nutshell, I hate my brother. How's that?

question: That's cool. Did you shoot him or something?
answer: No, not yet. I went home to confirm that the shithead was ditching school and a guy broke into the house and I called the cops and they picked me up for making a phoney phone call.

question: What do you care if your brother ditches school?
answer: Why should he get to ditch school when everybody else has to go?

question: You could ditch.
answer: I'd get caught.

question: So, you're pissed at him because he ditches and doesn't get caught?
answer: Basically.

question: Then your problem is you.
answer: Excuse me?

question: Excuse you. You oughta spend a little more time dealing with yourself and a little less time worrying about what your brother does. It's just an opinion. There's somebody you should talk to.
answer: If you say Ferris Bueller, you lose a testicle.

question: I can't believe you'd think up something like with a naked girl in a jacuzzi right in front of you.
answer: Come on, Ferris, answer his question.

question: Bathroom.
answer: I'd say...

question: Hello.
answer: Love.

question: And what is you loathe somebody? Are you going to say "love" every time you see them?
answer: It's better than "hello".

question: Hellos' generic.
answer: You wanna be generic?

question: I took a stand.
answer: No, Cameron. You wrecked a car.

question: It's okay.
answer: I have an idea. If you're interested.

question: I'm gonna handle it.
answer: I think this could work.

question: I had a great time today.
answer: Yeah. It was pretty cool.

question: You think Cameron's gonna be alright?
answer: Sure. He had to so it, I guess. His old man had it coming. He'll be okay. I'd be worried if he'd taken my idea.

question: You didn't have an idea, did you?
answer: Not a glimmer.

question: You're so smart.
answer: No. I'm just real loose. I'll call you tonight.

question: Thanks, Jeanie.
answer: No problem.

question: By the way, I borrowed some cash from you. I'll pay you back.
answer: You don't have to.

question: I want to.
answer: You don't have to. I've been ripping off your wallet for years.

question: Upstairs, Mom!
answer: Do you know a guy named Garth Volbeck?

question: Vaguely.
answer: Is he cool?

question: Ferris? How do you feel?
answer: 150% better, thank you. I'm much better, really. Please, don't make me stay home again. I want to go to school. I'm graduating in June and I...

question: Ferris. You're sick. There's no point pushing yourself and making it worse.
answer: Maybe you're right, Dad.
